abstract.p: Appending his name to a declaration that there is no justification for a war between Russia and Great Britain.

div.p: “We believe that there has not existed during the past 12 months, and that there does not exist now, any justification whatsoever for a war between Russia and Great Britain, and we should hold our Government guilty of the greatest crime towards this nation should they lead us or allow us to drift into war.”
Signed by DUDLEY, BATH, GIBRALTAR, COLERIDGE, CAMOYS, CHAS. DARWIN F.R.S. (and 35,000 others).

The following gentlemen will receive the names and addresses of all persons willing to sign this declaration. For forms, by which to collect signatures, apply to Mrs. Jacob Bright, 61, Onslow-square, S.W.
George Anderson, M.P., 13, Longridge-road, Earl's-court-road, S.W.
T. Burt, M.P., 2, Markham-square, Chelsea, S.W.
Peter Rylands, M.P., 76, St. George’s-square, S.W.
Burne Jones, The Grange, North-end-road, Fulham.

div.note: An account of the petition first appeared in The Times, 15 April 1878, p. 11; it noted that the declaration was presented at a public meeting held on Clerkenwell Green on Sunday, 14 April. CD's name appeared as a signatory in the version of the petition published in The Times, 1 May 1878, p. 10, which is the version presented here.

Following the decisive Russian victory in the Russo-Turkish War of 1877–8 and the signing of the Treaty of San Stefano on 3 March 1878, other European states were alarmed by the increase of Russian influence in the region. Britain had threatened to go to war, but by mid-May 1878 the crisis was averted when the Congress of Berlin was organised (Mackenzie 1993, pp. 240–2).
William Ward, 1st earl of Dudley; John Alexander Thynne, 4th marquess of Bath; Charles Waldgrave Sanford, Bishop of Gibraltar; John Duke Coleridge,1st Baron Coleridge; Thomas Stonor, 3d Baron Camoys.
